G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and the claims are for common‑law negligence.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 223A, § 3 because Defendant transacted business and committed tortious acts in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and Plaintiff’s causes of action arise from those acts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 & 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 & 2 because the cause of action arose in Suffolk County, at 1234 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts 02134.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: In Massachusetts, to prevail on a claim of negligence, a plaintiff must establish that: (a) the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care; (b) the defendant breached that duty; (c) the plaintiff suffered damages; and (d) the defendant’s breach was the actual and proximate cause of those damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim in Massachusetts: duty, breach, damages, and a causal relation between the breach and the damage. Although it phrases causation as a single element rather than separately labeling “actual and proximate” cause, that is the standard Massachusetts articulation of negligence elements and matches the substance of the proposition. The remainder of the opinion applies those elements, particularly focusing on duty, confirming this is the governing framework.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: In Massachusetts, to prevail on a claim of negligence, a plaintiff must establish that: (a) the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care; (b) the defendant breached that duty; (c) the plaintiff suffered damages; and (d) the defendant’s breach was the actual and proximate cause of those damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the elements the plaintiffs must prove to prevail on their negligence claims, including duty (breach of the duty to use reasonable care), actual loss (damages), and causation (that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss). While it does not separately label “actual and proximate cause,” its reference to causation as an essential element, with citation to Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281, aligns with the standard formulation in the proposition. Thus, the case directly supports the articulated elements of a Massachusetts negligence claim.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

Lussier v. Boston Edison Co., 32 Mass. A.raw_text: Lussier v. Boston Edison Co., 32 Mass. App. Ct. 984, 985 (1992)
Lussier v. Boston Edison Co., 32 Mass. A.proposition: Operators of motor vehicles in Massachusetts owe a duty to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances to avoid foreseeable harm to others using the roadway, including bicyclists.
Lussier v. Boston Edison Co., 32 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a criminal rape conviction and the denial of a brief continuance to obtain an expert witness regarding semen-testing evidence. It does not involve motor vehicles, roadway use, negligence standards, or duties owed to bicyclists or other road users. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about Massachusetts motorists’ duty of reasonable care toward bicyclists.
Lussier v. Boston Edison Co., 32 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt: the opinion addresses evidentiary issues and trial continuance in a rape prosecution, not motor vehicle duties or roadway negligence.]

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Operators of motor vehicles in Massachusetts owe a duty to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances to avoid foreseeable harm to others using the roadway, including bicyclists.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7\u00a7 11B\u201311B1/2.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations expressly recognize bicyclists as lawful users of public ways entitled to the protections of the rules of the road.

G.L. c. 89, \u00a7 1.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations expressly recognize bicyclists as lawful users of public ways entitled to the protections of the rules of the road.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violations of safety statutes and regulations, including those codified in G.L. c. 90 and G.L. c. 85, constitute evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a statute does not constitute negligence per se, but is only “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute was meant to prevent. It cites G.L. c. 138, § 69 as an example of such a safety statute and explains that its violation provides evidentiary support, not automatic liability. This squarely supports the proposition that violations of safety statutes and regulations (like those in G.L. c. 90 and c. 85) constitute evidence of negligence, rather than negligence per se.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.raw_text: Guinan v. Famous Players–Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501, 516 (1929)
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.proposition: Violations of safety statutes and regulations, including those codified in G.L. c. 90 and G.L. c. 85, constitute evidence of negligence.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the general rule that violation of a statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence, and it applies that rule to a safety regulation concerning inflammable motion picture film issued under statutory authority. While the specific regulation is not codified in G.L. c. 90 or c. 85, the case clearly stands for the broader Massachusetts principle that violations of safety statutes and regulations have evidentiary significance for negligence determinations. Thus it supports the proposition at the level of general doctrine about safety enactments as evidence of negligence.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence from which the jury could properly find that the delivery of the scrap film by Doherty to Shirley in a burlap bag was not a safe disposal of it. The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Massachusetts also imposes a duty on all persons to act with reasonable care to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm, including when engaging in ordinary activities such as opening car doors on public streets.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on causation and foreseeability in the context of a specific negligence claim, and it does not state or discuss any general Massachusetts duty rule about all persons acting with reasonable care in everyday activities like opening car doors. Without the majority opinion text or any language addressing a broad duty principle, this citation cannot reliably be said to support the claimed proposition. The quoted passage concerns whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm, not the existence or scope of a universal duty of care in ordinary activities.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.proposition: Massachusetts also imposes a duty on all persons to act with reasonable care to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm, including when engaging in ordinary activities such as opening car doors on public streets.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss general duty and foreseeability, but only in the specific context of a commercial premises owner’s duty to protect patrons from third-party criminal acts. It cites Mounsey and Carey to reaffirm that a store like Southland owes a duty of reasonable care to prevent injury by third persons, accidental, negligent, or intentional. It does not purport to describe a general duty imposed on “all persons” in everyday activities like opening car doors on public streets, so using this case for that broader proposition overstates its holding.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.relevant_excerpt: “Southland owed a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 [1973]) to prevent injury by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional (Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452 [1969]). Southland argues, however, that it owed no duty to the plaintiff in this case because the risk that led to the plaintiff's injury was not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant. Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646 (1990).”

Swan v. United States, 698 F. Supp. 2d 2.raw_text: Swan v. United States, 698 F. Supp. 2d 227, 234–35 (D. Mass. 2010)
Swan v. United States, 698 F. Supp. 2d 2.proposition: Distraction by cell phone use does not excuse a motorist’s failure to exercise reasonable care. A motorist is held to the standard of a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances, including observance of obvious cyclists in an adjacent bike lane.
Swan v. United States, 698 F. Supp. 2d 2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Swan v. United States is a prison-dental-care negligence case under the FTCA; it does not involve motor vehicle accidents, cell phones, motorists’ duties, or cyclists. The court’s analysis concerns standards of medical/dental care, expert testimony, and BOP policy, not roadway duties of reasonable motorists. Therefore it cannot be authoritative for the proposition that cell phone distraction does not excuse a motorist’s failure to exercise reasonable care toward cyclists in a bike lane.
Swan v. United States, 698 F. Supp. 2d 2.relevant_excerpt: First, absent exceptional circumstances in which negligence is sufficiently obvious to lie within common knowledge, the appropriate standard of care is to be testified to by experts. E.g., Palandjian v. Foster, 446 Mass. 100, 842 N.E.2d 916, 922 (2006); Haggerty v. McCarthy, 344 Mass. 136, 181 N.E.2d 562, 565 (1962). Neither party has submitted such testimony and the standard provided by 18 U.S.C. § 4042 is extremely general.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, any negligence by Plaintiff, if found, diminishes but does not bar recovery unless Plaintiff’s negligence exceeds the combined negligence of the defendant(s).

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, any negligence by Plaintiff, if found, diminishes but does not bar recovery unless Plaintiff’s negligence exceeds the combined negligence of the defendant(s).
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute and explains that a plaintiff’s contributory negligence only bars recovery if it is greater than the negligence of the defendants, and otherwise merely diminishes the plaintiff’s recovery in proportion to his fault. This directly matches the claimed proposition that plaintiff negligence diminishes but does not bar recovery unless it exceeds the combined negligence of the defendant(s).
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 56–57 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Determinations of negligence and comparative negligence are fact‑intensive inquiries typically reserved for the fact‑finder (the jury), rather than for resolution as a matter of law.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused on evidentiary sufficiency and proximate causation, arguing that the plaintiff’s proof was too speculative and that the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts. It does not discuss, endorse, or even mention the general principle that negligence and comparative negligence determinations are typically jury questions. If anything, it illustrates circumstances where the dissent believes those issues should be taken from the jury as a matter of law, which cuts against the claimed proposition rather than supporting it.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401,.proposition: Determinations of negligence and comparative negligence are fact‑intensive inquiries typically reserved for the fact‑finder (the jury), rather than for resolution as a matter of law.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether a social host owes any duty in negligence under specified circumstances and whether summary judgment was proper because no duty exists as a matter of law. It does not discuss negligence or comparative negligence as generally fact‑intensive questions for the jury; instead, it treats the existence of a duty as a pure question of law appropriate for resolution on summary judgment. Thus, it does not support the broad procedural proposition regarding negligence and comparative negligence being reserved for fact‑finders.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401,.relevant_excerpt: "The question whether the defendant owed a duty to travelers who might be injured by the negligent driving of an intoxicated guest who had been at the defendant's party presents 'a question of law [which is] to be determined by reference to existing social values and customs and appropriate social policy.' Wallace v. Wilson, ante 8, 12 (1991), and cases cited."

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867\u.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to: medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is a landlord–tenant and Chapter 93A case focused on emotional distress and warranty-of-habitability damages, not a general tort damages case. It does not state any broad rule that a negligence plaintiff may recover all categories of damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life. The discussion of damages is specific to emotional distress under Chapter 93A and diminution in rental value, so it does not support the expansive negligence-damages proposition cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867\u.relevant_excerpt:
On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.

... On the counterclaim of Gonzalez for breach of warranty of habitability, the judge concluded that Gonzalez was entitled to the difference between the actual value of the apartment in its defective condition and the fair market value of the apartment...

Tuttle v. McGeeney, 344 Mass. 200, 206\u.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to: medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.
Tuttle v. McGeeney, 344 Mass. 200, 206\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is about evidentiary issues, the effect of an auditor’s report, control of the vehicle, contributory negligence, and jury instructions. It does not discuss the scope or categories of recoverable damages (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, loss of enjoyment of life, etc.). Because the case never addresses what specific damages a plaintiff may recover when negligence is established, it does not support the cited damages proposition.
Tuttle v. McGeeney, 344 Mass. 200, 206\u.relevant_excerpt: In the first case, Marjorie Tuttle sought to recover for personal injuries and property damage to her automobile. The other action was by William Bowers to recover for personal injuries. ... 6. We think the instructions on the issue of control interwoven, as it was, with the issue of Bowers’s contributory negligence, tended to confuse and mislead the jury. The cases having been tried together, we are of opinion that the erroneous instructions were harmful to the defendant in each of the actions. Substantial justice requires that there be a new trial in each case.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including but not limited to pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as permitted by law, including filing fees and other allowable costs under the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and G.L. c. 261.
